newsitem.title: USA: CBOT soymeal ends sharply up on exports, El Nino.
newsitem.headline: CBOT soymeal ends sharply up on exports, El Nino.

text.p: July soymeal futures ended sharply higher Wednesday on talk of Chinese demand and worries over a developing El Nino weather pattern, traders said.
Soyoil futures also ended with solid gains, boosted by a rally in nearby soybeans.
Concerns that an El Nino weather pattern will cause drought in some oilseed and grain growing regions helped rally most CBOT soy complex prices, traders said.
El Nino has the potential to reduce monsoon rains in India and affect that country's oilseed production, according to the Hamburg-based newsletter Oil World.
"Due to El Nino, monsoon rains in India could be weaker and more erratic than usual," Oil World said, noting that an El Nino-inspired-drought in 1987 caused major production losses.
China was also seen buying 60,000 tonnes of soymeal from South American sources overnight for July/August delivery, traders in Asia said.

CBOT July soymeal settled up $7.40 per ton at $274.10 a ton, and other months were $2.00 to $5.20 higher. July soyoil settled up 0.22 cent a lb at 23.17 cents and other months ended down 0.02 to 0.19 higher.
On the day in soymeal trade, Continental Grain bought 400 lots December, LIT bought 400 July and Smith Barney sold 500 July, pit traders said.
In soyoil trade, ADM sold 300 lots August and bought 100 lots July, traders said.
Soymeal futures volume was estimated by CBOT at 30,000 lots, compared with Tuesday's actual volume of 28,862 lots. Soyoil volume was pegged at 16,00 lots against Tuesday's 18,640 lots.
